Write a summary about 'human aging'. Limit the output to 200 words. Please cite at least 3 references.
Human aging is a complex and multifaceted process that involves the deterioration of various physiological systems over time. As we age, our bodies undergo a range of changes that can affect our physical and mental health. These changes include a decline in physical strength and flexibility, a decrease in cognitive function, and an increased risk of age-related diseases such as Alzheimer's and cancer (Lopez-Otin et al., 2013).

One of the key factors contributing to human aging is the accumulation of damage to our cells and tissues over time. This damage can result from exposure to environmental stressors, such as UV radiation and pollution, as well as from internal processes, such as the production of free radicals (Harrison et al., 2014). Our cells have built-in mechanisms to repair this damage, but these mechanisms are not always effective, leading to the accumulation of damage and the development of age-related diseases.

Understanding the mechanisms of human aging is crucial for developing effective treatments and interventions to promote healthy aging and prevent age-related diseases (Finch & Austad, 2011).

References:

Finch, C. E., & Austad, S. N. (2011). The biology of aging. Academic Press.

Harrison, D. E., Strong, R., Sharp, Z. D., Nelson, J. F., Astle, C. M., Flurkey, K.,... & Miller, R. A. (2014). Rapamycin fed late in life extends lifespan in genetically heterogeneous mice. Nature, 509(7501), 502-506.

Lopez-Otin, C., Blasco, M. A., Partridge, L., Serrano, M., & Kroemer, G. (2013). The hallmarks of aging. Cell, 153(6), 1194-1217.

Human aging is the gradual and irreversible process of decline in physical, mental, and biological capabilities that occurs over time in living organisms, particularly in humans. This process is influenced by a combination of genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors. As people age, their bodies undergo changes that can affect their physical appearance, health, and cognitive abilities. These changes can include loss of muscle mass, bone density, and elasticity, as well as a decline in immune function and cardiovascular health.
